item.name: 10 Days in Africa
item.comment: Light filler and as a nice side effect you learn some African geography.

item.name: 20th Century
item.comment: ZooSim meets Industrial Waste.  Solid, a bit above the "Just Another Decent Euro" line, but it didn't leave me itching for more.  But, I'll probably seek out playing this at least one more time.

item.name: 221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
The 3 Commandments
item.comment: A fun/silly deduction/induction game, which in an of itself is a rare thing.  A little too long, but it's a party game, so people are usually having fun.

I love the concept and the ambition here, and the execution is quite solid. 

I've played 253, 861, 587 and 325.  All were good with 325 probably being the weakest.

item.name: 6 Nimmt!
item.comment:
This amazingly versatile game (2-10 players) can seem very random, but I&#039;m a strong
                                                   believer that there&#039;s actually a lot of control here. I&#039;m a big fan of simultaneous play
                                                   games, and this is a great game of psychology, hand management and risk taking.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Excellent civ building in half an hour.  I'm finding it improving over consecutive plays.

item.name: The 7th Continent
item.comment:
I love the idea here, but it ends up feeling flawed in the end.  

First of all, it's really a solo game and I'm not a big solo game fan, but this is the kind of game I am interested in solo.  But, the loss mechanic in particular feels broken.  That is, when you lose/die, you [i]start over[/i]?  There's enough total game here, and not enough fun/variety in repeating the early parts/trials that restarting feels fun.  So, there's an easy mode, but it's still easy enough to "lose" on that setting.

I wish there was a "loss" mechanic that felt like it had some stakes (so it wasn't just invulnerability) but didn't fully reset you after a loss.  I'm not a big fan of repeated play of the same scenario with the expectation that you'll carry knowledge over from earlier plays.

item.name: The 7th Continent: What Goes Up, Must Come Down
Abenteuer im Wichtelwald
item.comment: Very good abstract strategy despite the fact that it has the trappings of a children&#039;s game.

item.name: Accuse!
item.comment: A mediocre/poor deduction game with not enough going on to be worth it compared to anything else.  There are a plethora of superior deduction games and the bluffing/deduction aspect here isn't interesting or novel enough to be worth it.  Not horrible, just conspicuously not great.

item.name: Ace of Aces: Handy Rotary Series
item.comment: The system is exceptionally clever and the game isn't bad, but  it's not anything special in terms of gameplay.

item.name: Ace of Aces: Powerhouse Series
item.comment: The system is exceptionally clever and the game isn't bad, but  it's not anything special in terms of gameplay.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: Very good but it&#039;s easy to mess up the cash flow and can often lead to people being &quot;out of it&quot; for too long if they make what can seem like a minor error.

item.name: Ad Acta
item.comment: Interesting game of timing and stack management and I think the theme is clever.

item.name: Ad Liners
item.comment: Entertaining Apples-to-Apples-esque game with advertising slogans seemingly geared toward double entendres.

item.name: Adam & Eva
item.comment: Wonderful little "I cut, you choose" game with interesting hand management features along with good opportunities for bluffing and doublethink.

item.name: Adel Verpflichtet
item.comment: A classic, enjoyable, but it's a lot of double guessing.

item.name: Advanced Civilization
item.comment: Yes, it's a classic, but however good it is, it doesn't really justify it's play time.  I only occasionally have the urge to play it again, and it's been years since I have.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: Ok, a lot of randomness, but a lot of fun.  Dun-dun-dun-dun, dun-dun-dun..

item.name: Aeon's End
item.comment:
I'm a sucker for games like this.  Huge abundance of game setup options (mages, supply cards, enemies) which feel interestingly different.  And, it's fun.

My biggest problem with it is that some / many of the enemies are very very difficult, even on "easy mode",  and while I like the option of having a challenge, I like an option of having a chance of winning with new players too without only playing the easiest nemeses over and over.

That said, still great.

item.name: Aeon's End: Legacy of Gravehold – The Ruins
Age of Steam
item.comment: A bit unforgiving and the scoring is a bit athematic, but the combined execution is very strong.

item.name: Agemonia
item.comment: Only played tutorials so far, but really outstanding scenario design, interesting core action-tradeoff mechanism, and great exploration mechanics yield a really really engaging experience.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: Quite good, but feels a bit too much like an optimization puzzle rather than a game and way too long.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
Akropolis
item.comment: It's fine.  It really doesn't feel like anything special so I'm a bit flummoxed by the buzz.   It's not bad, but it feels really "basic" in the sense that it's all been done before and it isn't that exceptionally well created.  But, it's enjoyable, it's fine.

item.name: Aladdin's Dragons
item.comment:
It tends to bog down a lot, but the game is better if played
quickly.

item.name: Alexandros
item.comment: See <a href=http://server.boardgamestuff.com:8000/gray/blog/Games/Reviews/Alexandros.html>my blog comments</a>

item.name: Alibi
item.comment: Wow, look at that art.

item.name: Am Fuß des Kilimandscharo
item.comment: I was hoping there was more than just a really simple kids game here, but it appears that straightforward.

item.name: Das Amulett
item.comment:
Outstanding two tiered auction game.  If you&#039;re not careful,
certain combos of powers can be unbalancing though.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: Outstanding and solid Knizia game of auctions and building.  I got burnt out on it for a year or so, but it's retained staying power through that.

item.name: Ancient Knowledge
item.comment:
Clever and thematic engine builder with a couple of especially appealing mechanics.  Cards in your tableau fade-awy which means they only provide their ability for some amount of time and there's an interesting manipulation game to keep them in play or accelerate their fade, while at the same time trying to avoid badness that happens if they fade away too fast, and benefit from the goodness (additional card draw capability) when they do fade away.

The theme and art work really well, and I'm interested in playing again.

Why only a 7?  I don't know how much the combos are that interesting, and rating could go up if/when I play again.

item.name: Andromeda
item.comment: I normally don't like area influence games, but the "probabilistic area influence" quality this has really feels rather fun and clever.

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Neither my favorite dexterity game nor my favorite animal-stacking-themed game.

item.name: Antike
item.comment: Wonderful civilization development game.  Extremely short turns allow for a feeling of constant engagement.  The action selection mechanism is simple, elegant, clever and well-balanced.

item.name: Apex Theropod Deck-Building Game
item.comment: Kickstarter edition

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment:
Perhaps one of the best party games ever. It has an extremely questionable level of
                                                   skill involved, but is a huge amount of fun, and reasonably plays as few as 4 or as many
                                                   as 10. This will continue to get pulled out for a long time. Often, this is a very amusing
                                                   and light note on which to end a gaming session.

item.name: Arbos
item.comment: This is much better with adults if played on the &quot;very hard&quot; setting where the tree is extremely unstable.

item.name: Ark
item.comment:
Beautiful artwork, interesting if not especially amazing game, and it's desperately in need of a reference card. Without it, it was common to get confused about the various card placement limitations. I'm also not so sure there's much plan ahead, but it's cute and small.
(2 plays)

item.name: Ark Nova
item.comment: I enjoyed it but I think I'd almost always prefer to play Terraforming Mars when I want to play this "genre".

item.name: Around the World in 80 Days
item.comment: Very good. It combines some nice mechanics (card drafting, action selection, standard race game) with a clever twist (two different "race" goals) and is well executed. The clever part I especially like: each player is completing both to get back to London first (fewest number of game turns) as well as first (fewest number of "days" spent by playing cards). The game mechanics work out nicely such that these goals are somewhat in conflict; by delaying an extra game turn or two, you can likely finish the race in a fewer number of days. The way the win conditions are set up (must finish in under 80 days and must not finish last in game turns), it works rather well. This isn't a "big hit" kind of game, but it's fun. Especially if you enjoy unusual race games. It has a slightly similar feel to Marco Polo Expedition.

item.name: Ascending Empires
item.comment: Outstanding mixture of strategic play and theme with the dexterity element being nice fun and not getting in the way of the game itself.

item.name: Ashes Reborn: Rise of the Phoenixborn
Astro Knights
item.comment: Great alternate version of Aeon's End.  Some big positives: faster setup, smaller base game, variable cities being defended.  Downsides: I like the Aeon's End art better, I like the uniform piles better, and I like the variation in the monsters more.  But still great.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment: I enjoyed this a lot but wow is it long.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: I like this a lot but substantially prefer it with the following variant, when playing with more than 2:  Instead of connection causing a win, it allows the connector to draw 6 cards.  This creates a more consistent overall feel for the game, to me.

item.name: Attila
item.comment: A underplayed stock/influence game with a much less business-like theme.

item.name: Attribute
item.comment: Plays best when the topics are specific to the group, eg, people at the table, common experiences, places, etc.

item.name: Aurum
item.comment: Yet another clever trick taking game.  It's fun, and like most clever trick taking games, especially fun the first play or few while you're figuring out how it works.

item.name: Authentic Demolition Derby
item.comment: Nice bits, cute idea, but it's simply not fun enough for how random/mundane it feels.

item.name: The Awful Green Things From Outer Space
Balanx
item.comment: This is a nice tactical game with a clever use of it&#039;s tilting board.

item.name: Balloon Cup
item.comment: An outstanding addition to the Kosmos/Rio Grande 2-player line.  I think it may be more luck based than it initially seems, but it&#039;s fun in any case.

item.name: Bambuti
item.comment: Underrated essentially abstract card game for two.  A fair amount of luck, but some very interesting choices.

item.name: Barbarossa
item.comment:
This is a great game, but it can be very sensitive to the
right group and the right approach.  The fact that it involves sculpting clay makes many treat it as a lighter game than it is.  (not that it is THAT heavy)

item.name: Bärenpark
item.comment: Perhaps my favorite polyomino game, with a fun drafting mechanism and a satisfying set of constraints and interlocking mechanisms for building your zoo.

item.name: Bargain Hunter
item.comment:
This is probably my favorite of the large number of whist-variant card games out
                                                   there. Trump changes on a trick-to-trick basis, the contents of the tricks won
                                                   matters, and the theme makes at least as much sense as any trick-taking game theme
                                                   does. Additionally, it plays with 3 very well in addition to working well with 4.

item.name: Basari
item.comment: Outstanding doublethink game.

item.name: Batik
item.comment: Clever and cute geometry/dexterity game that plays very quickly.

item.name: Battle Beyond Space
item.comment: What I love about this game is the feeling that you are piloting a squadron of ships that you are in control of, but not in total control of, and that gives it a chaotic battlefield vibe that feels very cinematic.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment:
This one is my favorite by Knizia. In the first two months of owning it, I played 10
                                                   times. In the second 2 months, another 10. Since then, it&#039;s tapered off some, but it still
                                                   comes out on a regular basis. I&#039;m sure it will hit 30 times by the end of the year (2002).
                                                   This game has some of the same feel as Lost Cities, but with more depth and options.
                                                   The tactics cards (and number 10 cards) are all that&#039;s been added over the original
                                                   game

item.name: Battleball
item.comment: A pretty basic run-around-on-a-grid game with a nice mechanic for the slow pieces being better tacklers than the fast pieces.  Nice minis.

item.name: Battlestations
item.comment: Almost a role playing game.  In fact, it's might be over the line, but it's so close to self-adjudicating I'm happy to call it a board game.  The best implementation of the whole "multi-scale" game thing I've ever played (ship-to-ship scale and crew scale)

item.name: Beowulf: The Legend
item.comment: Oh, I so wanted to like this. After the first play, I was luke warm. One third of the way into the second play, I was hopeful, it looked like there might be some interesting and deeper hand management decisions than it originally seemed. Then, luck happened. I like luck in games. A lot. But, Beowulf has luck in the same (and only) place it has strategy and tactics: hand management. In addition to the luck of the draw, which is reasonably small and the usual factor in hand management games, it has the so called "risks", particularly during "major episodes" which are basically a magnified "luck of the draw". A good draw in a mid-episode risk is very beneficial. A bad draw in a mid-episode risk is very bad. If the luck were instead somewhere else, say in the selection of the order of the episodes, or in some other aspect of the game, it might not ruin it, but I think the potential variability of the swings of luck that so fundamentally and directly affect the core of the game eliminates too much of the impact of earlier decisions. At least I know I don't need another big box filling up shelf space.

item.name: The Best of Dragon Magazine Games
Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: This new Avalon Hill game is a lot of theme, which didn't really engage me, and only a very little game. It's a sort of neat idea, but not especially and the execution is mediocre. The components are nice, and there are some creative ideas, but I didn't see much I really thought was compelling.

item.name: Between Two Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: Good twist on Between Two Cities, maybe better, maybe not much.

item.name: Beyond Competition
item.comment: Slight shelf wear, but quite good condition.

item.name: Beyond the Sun
item.comment: My favorite worker placement game.  Rich theme with interesting choices.  Better with 2, heavily due to it playing faster.

item.name: Beyond the Sun: Leaders of the New Dawn
The Big Idea
item.comment:
This is a party game, and a good one, but I&#039;ve seen people
take it seriously, in which case it is no fun.  As a party game, it&#039;s a blast.

item.name: Big Kini
item.comment: Good exploration game, but when it comes down to it, another player summed it up: "more of the same". It's got nice mechanisms, bits, and all that, though it lacks a feeling of tension.

item.name: Billabong
item.comment: Very good tactical abstract.

item.name: Black Vienna
item.wishlistcomment: oop

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: Good minor variant on the full size game.

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager – The Card Game
Blue Moon
item.comment: Grows on me each time I play it.  Impressive amount of breadth and depth to the gameplay as well as very nice art and quick playing time.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: Initial impressions are very positive.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
An outstanding light trading game. It can be played in a very friendly way, or
                                                   cutthroat, and is extremely fun, either way. The art is adorable and the theme is great.
                                                   This is the ultimate game of trading for

item.name: Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Game
Buy Low Sell High
item.comment: Motley Fool Edition.  I love the basic market mechanic here.

item.name: BuyWord
item.comment: Can even be played semi-cooperatively and retain it's fun.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: Very cute, simple bluff, counter-bluff, special-powers, awesome-foam-handgun game. Unfortunately, it's outrageously expensive for what it is. Again, as a straight small package card game, I'd probably pick it up. As is, I can pass.

item.name: Cabanga!
item.comment:
Better with actual throwing and yelling "Cabanga!"

Cute filler like a shallower 6 nimmt!

item.name: Caesar & Cleopatra
item.comment: Very solid flag influence game.  The hidden/public cards mechanic feels less significant in play than it seems it should.

item.name: Café International
item.comment: Cute, light game of xenophobia.

item.name: Café International: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment: Very successful translation of a good game into a good card game.

item.name: Call my Bluff
item.comment: Outstanding.  Most people would do a lot better at this game if they more reliably did the math.  The endgame is especially interesting, whether to participate or watch, following elimination.

item.name: Camelot
item.comment: Great concept, not so great game.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment:
Another outstanding dice game. This is the ultimate game of brinkmanship. I vastly
                                                   prefer the plastic red stop sign board to the

item.name: Candamir: The First Settlers
item.comment: Too slow and non-interactive.  It feels like it could be good, but isn't quite there.

item.name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens
item.comment: A couple of very clever mechanisms but can be overly hurt by bad play by others.  I wish there were more strategic options but it is still fun.

item.name: Cape Horn
item.comment: Dry but fun, can have a high &quot;screw your opponent&quot; aspect.

item.name: Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game
item.comment: I really enjoyed this and felt it maintained the superhero feel without being catastrophically unbalanced (the usual problem).

item.name: Capitol
item.comment: Somehow uninteresting.

item.name: Capt'n Clever
item.comment: Fun simple game.

item.name: The Captain Is Dead
item.comment: Fun, tense, atmospheric co-op.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
Carcassone is a clever and compelling spin on the free form tile laying genre. A
                                                   variety of scoring options make for interesting strategic decisions that must be
                                                   adapted as the board evolves. The mechanism of not allowing a

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: German version, 100% compatible with English version, no language.

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment: More of the same, and the art's not as good.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: Outstanding race and card management game.

item.name: Cat in the Box: Deluxe Edition
item.comment: Many years ago, I sort of burned out on Whist-like trick taking games even though I enjoyed them, and liked many of the clever ones like Drahtseilakt and Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde, I avoided them somewhat for years. Well, between The Crew and this new one, that's over. This is extremely clever and actually deserving of it's "quantum" theme.

item.name: Catch Phrase Junior
item.comment: Great version of the standard game, and the "junior" doesn't mean "lame".
item.conditiontext:
Electronic Catchphrase Junior.
New in box.
offervalue:15

item.name: Catch Phrase!
item.conditiontext:
Original Electronic version.
New in box.
offervalue:22

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: It's outstanding, but it's not quite as earth shaking as many have made it out to be. It's long, and it can have some downtime, which is not a good combination. It seems that usually it will be quite engaging with little downtime, but the length detracts. Above and beyond that, there's a nicely interlocking set of mechanisms, but nothing amazingly clever or revolutionary. It's a very well done resource management game with some novelty in the mechanisms. A definite buy, but it's not Puerto Rico. Even with experienced players, it's going to take 100-150 minutes, maybe more.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta
item.comment:
Originally, I rated this an 8.8.  And thenI haven't played it in over 15 years and I should pull it out again, I don't have the yearning I usually do for games I rate an 8.8, so I think the enthusiasm of it being better than Caylus, IMO, bot the best of me.  Rating might go up again if/when I play it again :)

Original comment: All of the good parts of Caylus, without all of the length.

item.name: Celebrities
item.comment: As party games go, this is pretty good, but very dependent on the group, even more so than most party games.

item.name: Celtica
item.comment: Beautiful artwork, but the randomness of the game so totally dwarfs the decision-making that the minimal decisons that remain are simple exercises in frustration.  Oh well.

item.name: Challengers!
item.comment: I like the idea of this a lot. The game itself is good/fine and I want to give it another try, because maybe it's better than it seemed at first play.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: I'm sufficiently mediocre at chess and many people I might otherwise play with are actually good it is less enjoyable, even if played with handicaps.  That said, it's possible to play quickly, and has interesting choices and is available all over.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: Fun trading negotiation.  The negotiation can be played seriously but amiably, while many other negotiation games tend to feel more cutthroat.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment: I really wish this were better.

item.name: Ciao, Ciao...
item.comment: Interesting &quot;pure&quot; bluffing game.  Doesn&#039;t hit the spot for many, but it&#039;s a clever distillation of a mechanic.

item.name: Civolution
item.wishlistcomment: Appealing theme, but Feld, but...

item.name: Clank! In! Space!: A Deck-Building Adventure
Claustrophobia
item.comment: Richly tactical and thematic game. The tactical feel is different in a good way from the more standard grid based tactical miniatures games.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
Clifford the Big Red Dog Happy Birthday Game
Code 777
item.comment: As straight clue-driven deduction games go, about as good as it gets.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: I like it about as much as I can for a game I am catastrophically awful at.

item.name: Comic Hunters
item.comment: They took a few fine, but unremarkable games and bolted them together into a fine game that's slightly better than each of the individual parts.  If the theme (comic book collecting, not super-heroes) is especially appealng it might be a step more engaging.

item.name: Compatibility
item.comment:
Fun "couples" game whether with actual couples or random pairings. 

Yields nice excitement moments with unexpected matches and the converse.

Best played with a minor variant: When cards match exactly (same card, same position) those cards are removed from the game for that partnership.  This prevents the "accidental cheating" mode where a particular partnership associates a particular image with a huge fraction of words.  It also fixes the degenerate "always choose Puffin" strategy, but hopefully you don't play with people who would do that, but the accidental "associate everything with Puffins" does happen.

item.name: Cootie
item.comment: This is the rating as a kids game.  As an adult game, it's not a game.

item.name: Cornerstone
item.comment: Cool concept, and maybe if I played without the dexterity/balance element I'd find it more satisfying.

item.name: Couture
item.comment:
A clever little auction game with a simple but novel-feeling bid allocation process that plays into an otherwise straightforward set-collection and auction feedback game.  Definitely fun, and the theme is a good relatively underrepresented one, but it feels a little under-balanced and like it could be even better.

But a solid little auction game.

item.name: Cowabunga
item.comment: Enh. Cute mechanic and nice integration of cardplay and memory, but in the end I'm not sure I believe your decisions (what card to play) really makes much of a difference.

item.name: The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine
Crocodile Pool Party
item.comment: How little can you throw in one of these boxes?  Not as awful as many would lead you to believe, but it's one clever bit is that it's a abstract tactical game where your pieces are randomly valued.  It works ok, but just ok.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: One of the richest dexterity/skill games out there.  Personally, I prefer the slower boards rather than the waxed up frictionless surfaces some people prefer to play on.

item.name: Dance of Ibexes
item.comment: A boardgame (barely) version of "6 nimmt!" It's fun and it's got some good twists above and beyond the basic gameplay, which closely resembles 6 nimmt!, but in the end, I'm not sure it adds that much. What does seem possible is that this may do better with fewer players while the original prefers more like 5 or 6 players. The tiles are a bit annoying compared to cards and the whole aspect of everyone having the option to buy cards before each turn really messes up the pacing. Fun, but I may mostly stick to 6 nimmt!, and I'm usually a big fan of novelty.4

item.name: Darter
item.comment: Fun two-player with just enough theme that it might not be called "abstract".  A variety of interesting strategies are available.

item.name: Décorum
item.comment: Cooperative deduction! A theme of passive aggressive home decoration! So novel, so interesting, and lots of fun. I've mostly played with 2, but also one of the multi-player scenarios and both work very well. The theme is perfectly captured, not so hard, and the mechanics work well and are interestingly divergent from the usual deduction game full of specific but oblique clues. Here the clues are not at all oblique, but are rife with ambiguity. Very neat.

item.name: Decrypto
item.comment:
Strong, clever and fun cluing game. It's better with people who are more experienced with cluing games.

It's always hard to explain the rules/procedure, but it flows and works well once you run through it.

item.name: Deep Space D-6
item.comment:
One of the best solo games I've played.  Dice placement ends up feeling remarkably thematic.

The different ships are quite distinctive and interesting..

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: Engaging, tactically interesting and fun dungeon crawl.  The permutations of characters, abilities, treasures, scenarios and monsters are distinct feeling and rich in theme.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark – Quest Compendium – Volume One
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Diamonds Club
item.comment: Good interlocking system game, but a bit too decoupled from the theme.  I don't think I'd often want to play this over numerous other "system games" (Puerto Rico, Goa, etc).

item.name: Dice Throne: Season Two – Gunslinger v. Samurai
Dilbert: Corporate Shuffle
item.comment: Fun and the cartoons are cute.  Not as much  "staying power" for me as for some.

item.name: Discover: Lands Unknown
item.comment:
Good exploration game.  Very much like a lightweight version of Seventh Continent.  I enjoyed both my plays with one big qualifier.  In our second game we got to a point where things seemed unsolvable and we gave up.  We enjoyed the game up to that moment.  

Deconstructing what happened afterward, it turned out we faced one obstacle (avoiding specific spoilers) early on that you can get past via brute force or use of tools.  Thematically, these should lead to the "same thing" or at least doing it via the use of tools should produce a strictly better outcome than using brute force.  Except, that the critical component for us to win was only available by doing the brute force thing, and doing it via tools failed to get us that thing and, thematically it wouldn't have even made sense to go back and "do it again" via brute force even though I guess via the rules it's allowed.

I worry that this kind of semi-nonsensical-but-technically-valid might be common in the "unique" procedurally generated game mode (and be harder to patch than in software procedural generation games).

item.name: Discoveries: The Journals of Lewis & Clark
Disney Big Thunder Mountain Railroad
item.comment: It's a Disney World ride-themed (?!) deck builder board game with marbles that roll down a mountain. Intriguing. But, like the marbles, it's all downhill from there. The mountain is flaky/unreliable and the game is basic. The weird attempt at a rotating mountain (?) as a dispenser only mostly works. At least they tried. It's not really bad, but not good either.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Really solid party game, and the art totally makes the game.  I prefer more elaborate "hints", since I think it makes the game more fun, but it's fun however you play it.

item.name: A Dog's Life
item.comment: Ugh.  Cute theme, but long, random, and dull.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment:
A compelling "sight reading" game where figuring out the strategy for the particular Kingdom (ie, set of cards) being used is a lot of the game.  Plays fast and is very addictive.  100 plays later and it remains a winner.

Also, it plays shockingly well with my 6-year-old; the ability to play with essentially open hands helps, but the mechanics are not that complex when it comes down to it.

item.name: Dorfromantik: The Board Game
item.comment: Very successfully executes a "chill" tile placement game for two players for us.  The in-game and legacy goals work well together.  A little bit of push your luck in a way that doesn't feel like that, and a satisfying shared puzzle.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: A game with a lot of luck, but a really nice bit of gameplay which involves running from the erupting volcano. Certainly not the deepest game, but there are interesting tactical choices and even some strategic planning. Some of the turn timing seems to introduce more luck than is warranted though. Running from a volcano is entertaining.

item.name: Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde
item.comment: Amazingly clever, remarkably subtle, frustrating and fun.

item.comment: A perfectly fine, relatively generic drafting game with nice dino-meeples.

item.name: Dragon Eclipse

item.name: The Dresden Files Cooperative Card Game

item.name: Dune: Imperium
item.comment: Some cleverness in the cardplay  and the theme works, but just not enough.

item.name: Dungeon Twister

item.comment: Plant based engine/tableau builder with some nice mechanics where you grow one thing to 'feed" another to feed another and it cycles.  Feels very thematic.  The similarities to Wingspan are clear but different enough.

item.name: Easy Come, Easy Go
item.comment: Good. It's an exceedingly simple dice game with a great deal of luck and many of the decisions are fairly obvious. That said, it's quite fun and very quick. There is a bit more to the game than it seems at first, but that's not to say there are great depths to be plumbed here. Deduct 4 points from the rating if you don't like light, luck-heavy dice games.

item.name: Eclipse: New Dawn for the Galaxy
Ecos: First Continent
item.comment: I feel like I like this more than most people I have opportunities to play with.  The "bingo" mechanic is appealing and the power combos feel like what I want from a combo-building game.  It goes on a bit too long, or maybe we just play it too slow.

item.name: Edel, Stein & Reich
item.comment: Basari is much better

item.name: Egizia
item.comment: At some level, this is Just Another Good Euro.  Better than decent, and interesting choices and mechanics, but not amazing.  Definitely good though.

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment: Much better than Candamir. It doesn't feel that innovative, but it is a well crafted combination of familiar mechanics along with a few clever bits. If you like Catan-style development games, this is definitely worth a try.

item.name: Electronic Catchphrase
item.comment: A great beeping filler game.

item.name: Elefantenparade
item.comment: A very nice, simple, but sometimes subtle game.

item.name: Elementals
item.comment: Simple slap-jack style speed recognition games with attractively illustrated little elemental men. If you like that sort of thing, it's pretty good.

item.name: Elements
item.comment:
Works substantially better with 3 than with 5 players.
The random card draws introduces a little randomness yet
the fewer players gives the players more control.  With 3,
it&#039;s a good game.  With 5 it&#039;s just ok.

item.name: Emira
item.comment: Interesting dynamics and combinations of mechanics.  I wish it felt a little quicker paced, but that could just be a learning curve issue.  Feels well balanced and with an impressive set of strategic options.

item.name: Empire's End
item.comment: I like what this game is trying to do, but in the end, while the premise is admirable, it's just less fun to play an empire in decline.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: Decent, but nothing deeply special to be offered here.

item.name: EOS: Island of Angels
item.comment:
(based on a single play so far)
The first play was a bit disappointing, both in terms of length and one player seeming to run away with it based substantially on initial luck.

But, the mechanisms are appealing, the game is beautiful and the asymmetry seems interesting.  I will definitely play again, and it may go up to a 7 or down to a 6, but it seems unlikely to go far from that but you never know.

A bit of a "kitchen sink" game with a pile of mechanics, but I like most/all of them so that can be OK, and they feel a little more coherent than some kitchen sink games.

item.name: Epic Card Game: Guardians of Gowana

item.comment: A nice extension of Roll Through The Ages with nice city miniatures.  At the end of the day I think I still prefer RttA, but as games that add complexity to a solid foundation, this one succeeds more than most.

item.name: Escape from 100 Million B.C.
item.comment:
Run-around exploration game.  In the right mood, this can be very entertaining.  As strategy gaming it's rather tepid.  But, the notion of escorting time anomalies (people from history) around a wilderness while running away from and occasionally fighting dinosaurs while you pick up parts of your space ship is thematically delightful.

It's very swingy, but that feels like its nature.

item.name: Escape from the Hidden Castle
item.comment:
Good fun kids push-your-luck game, but I think Viva Topo is better.

(rated as a kids game)

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Evacuation
item.wishlistcomment: Appealing crowdfunding.

item.name: Evenfall
item.comment:
(one play)
A good engine builder with some clever bits (the "inner" and "outer" circles of cards) and relatively tightly constructed.

It's long and like a lot of games of this type, feels like it would be a lot better if it were somehow shortened/sped up.  The theme/art are nice, but unfortunately more than a little disconnected from the mechanics and aren't a great mnemonic help.

It's also a bit of a kitchen-sink game, that has a little bit of everything which I'm increasingly feeling is a bit overdone.  But, I enjoyed one play and will probably not seek it out again, but wouldn't avoid it.
item.wishlistcomment: Felix put it on his wishlist, sounds interesting

item.name: Evil Corp.
item.wishlistcomment: Felix put it on his watchlist, sounds interesting

item.name: Exit: The Game – The Abandoned Cabin
Expeditions: Around the World
item.comment: I find the art for Wildlife Adventure more appealing and clearer for gameplay and the games are so close, I'll play that over Expedtion...

item.name: Fabled Fruit
item.comment:
Fun evolving action selection. I actually wish it had a theme that made more sense.

The Fable mechanism is nice, but not anything exceptional.

item.name: Fact or Crap
item.comment: One of the worse "trivia" games I've ever played.  Dumb/bad/uninteresting questions, stupid gameplay.  Avoid.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment: This is really entertaining and a novel feeling puzzle game, and the machine names and art are the icing on the cake.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: Interesting. I actually think it's fairly good, but I have a nagging feeling there is less subtlety to the game than it seems. The art is cute and the odd "Engrish" isn't too distracting, though it seems common that players have a hard time with the fact that "Close All {1 fairies}" actually means "All players turn 1 fairy card face down". In any case, this also wins some points for cleverness by using a Magic: The Gathering style draft for card selection as well as a somewhat novel card flipping mechanism.

item.name: Familienbande
item.comment:
Seriously underrated game.  This is fun game of hidden goals and gradual manipulation.

I need to try it with a house rule where you can draw from a choice of 3 face-up cards instead of just drawing from the deck.  It seems like it would eliminate some of the occasionally substantial luck and not slow things down much.

item.name: Fast Sloths
item.comment: Clever race combination game, reminiscent of the good things about Elfenland, but faster and creative in several ways.

item.name: Felicity: The Cat in the Sack
Fiese Freunde Fette Feten
item.comment: Great theme, great gameplay, great art.  I love the multi-dimensional optimization and how that interplays with the auctions as well as the whole timing game.

item.name: Figaro
item.comment: A little to chaotic without being interesting at the same time.

item.name: Fiji
item.comment: Fun, brain-twisting decisions with a generous share of double- and triple-guessing.  It's light, quick and chaotic enough to make those qualities fun and engaging.  With 3, it's tactical and interesting double-guessing.  With 4 or 5, it's more chaotic, but still fun.

item.name: Finstere Flure
item.comment: Outstanding game.

item.name: First in Flight

item.name: Flamecraft
item.comment:
Worker placement resource management with dragons making dessert and whatnot. A friend called this "too twee", and he's not exactly wrong, but I like gratuitous theme juxtaposition.

It's adorable, and under that is a fine game, but a somewhat generic one, and I'm sort of meh on a lot of worker placement games, so account for that bias.

I feel like there's something interesting with chaining planned actions, but it often felt too easy to get the right resources. Cute though!

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Extreme Danger

item.name: Floriado

item.name: For Science!: Exclusive Bonus Role Cards

item.name: Forbidden Jungle

One play, rating might go up, definitely want to play again.

I like the Forbidden series.  I like scifi.  This shouldn't be called "Forbidden Jungle" it should be called "Forbidden Planet", but I guess that name is already taken.

I like the way the threat management works here and the board geometry manipulation.

It's solidly designed and fun but I'm not sure there's enough new there to differentiate it.  In a prior decade this may have been a must-have but there's a lot of great tableau builders now.

                                                   circles around trying to knock chickens off your barn, but if you hit your paddle at the

One of the most intense and positive gaming experiences on a consistent basis.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion Expansion
Mage Wars Arena
item.comment:
Wow, this game is really something.  It's a CCG-style game with a substantial tactical combat element that attempts to emulate the feel of dueling mages.  I think it succeeds.  

It is intimidating, in the sense that each player has a "spellbook" (literally a binder full of cards) with dozens of unique cards in at least 6 or 7 major varieties, any one of which often has special power text, and most of which have various special modifier words, which come from a codex of dozens of descriptors.  And, each turn you have access to a huge portion of your spellbook, so the learning curve is a bit steep.  Both of us playing have played many games of this style/complexity before, and in actual play, the complexity wasn't bad, but it's definitely a bit overwhelming.

The game is fun, tactically interesting, and ended up quite even with some interesting exchanges and interactions.  In the end, I think this is a "lifestyle game" though.  The complexity is more of the magnitude of a game like Dungeons & Dragons or Magic: The Gathering, and it seems like it would shine with both players being dedicated to and familiar with the game. I could see this game potentially being very rewarding if one were to make a bit of a "lifestyle" of it.  That said, it was fun even as a one off.

In the end, it's thematic, well-balanced, and extremely complex in a compelling way.
