item.comment:
This is probably one of the best games incorporating a substantial memory
                                                   component. Memory games, as a class, are often children&#039;s games because they give
                                                   kids a chance against adults. The memory aspect here has that effect to some degree,
                                                   but the cardplay and sheer volume of cards make it not the dominating aspect of the
                                                   game. Lots of quick fun, especially with pre-teen aged kids.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: One of the better betting games out there, along with Royal Turf.

item.name: Marvel Champions: The Card Game
item.comment:
Very well done evolution of the Sentinels of the Multiverse structure (unique hero decks vs unique villain deck with minions, powers, and events) with Marvel heroes, dinner deck building and interesting hero and villain decks.

Still very fiddly and I prefer Sentinels most of the time, but different enough to be worthwhile in it's own right.

item.name: Marvel Champions: The Card Game – Doctor Strange Hero Pack
Marvel Champions: The Card Game – The Green Goblin Scenario Pack
Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men
item.comment: It's better than Quarriors, and isn't the same, but is certainly in that vein.  I wish that the powers/interactions felt more interesting.  It's fine.

item.name: Marvel Heroes
item.comment:
A bit too long, and to really immerse oneself in the theme, which is much of the appeal, it would take even longer.
The rating may go up with a little more experience though.

item.name: Marvel United
item.comment: My favorite fast coop

item.name: Marvel: Remix
item.comment: I liked Fantasy Realms which this is based on, but I like this a lot better. The theme works better too. It's very random, but that's ok for a 10 minute game with interesting choices and good game dynamics. The game produces a nice (simple) implicit narrative which is rare in quite so short a game. A really great filler.

item.name: Masons
item.comment: Good decisions, engaging play, not earthshaking, but very good.

item.name: Massive Darkness 2: Enemy Box – Rainbow Crossing
Massive Darkness 2: Hellscape
item.comment:
Fun dice fest with appealingly diverse character mechanics. Plays better/faster with fewer players, but relatively quick paced once set up, which is substantial.

Rules are pretty good for a game this baroque, but there's a lot of fiddliness.  The table presence is great.

item.name: Massive Darkness 2: Heroes & Monster Set – Bards & Tinkerers vs Metal Angel
Massive Darkness 2: Heroes & Monster Set – Monks & Necromancers vs The Paragon
Masters of Mutanite
item.comment: I backed it because it sounded like it had some clever bits and I'm a sucker for superhero themed games. So, I came in with perhaps lowered expectations, but it definitely exceeded those. It's quick, lightweight and the clever parts (deck building by moving around the city and throwing objects at each other for effects) are quite nicely integrated and clever. It's not deep, but it's obvious that's not what it's trying to be, and it is fun and has interesting choices, and feels simultaneously like a superhero fighting game and a deck builder.

item.name: Mäuse-Rallye
item.comment: An entertaining flicking game, typically used as filler.  I bet it plays well with kids, too ;-)

item.name: Mecanisburgo
item.comment: It's got too much going on and is way too long but is very cool.  If they stripped out half of the mechanics and shortened it, but kept the theme, core mechanics, and some of the chrome, it could be quite good.

item.name: Mechs vs. Minions
item.comment: Outstanding coop programming with fun, interesting gameplay and a stunningly produced game.  Scenarios are great and eminently replayable.  The chaos is nicely manageable and fun, with opportunities for cleverness and confusion.  One of the best new games in a long time.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: One of the best auction games, ever.  The auctions combining money and "slots on the ship" interact in compelling and deep ways.

item.name: Medici vs Strozzi
item.comment: Interesting and engaging, if a bit dry.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Not so much better than Battle Cry.

item.name: Mercurial
item.comment: The group I played thi with hated it.  I'll probably try to play it again with a different group and see if the feeling changes.  I wanted this to be an interesting evolution of the kinds of mechanics in Century Spice Road, but I think it falls far short, with fiddliness that adds little and decisions that aren't nearly so interesting.

item.name: Mesopotamia
item.comment: Nice exploration/development/pick-up-and-deliver game. The actions cards are a bit more variable in power level than I'd like ideally (ie, some are very good, some are quite poor) but it's still nice. The exploration element here is very light, but I like it. Plays reasonably quickly too.

item.name: Mindbug: First Contact
item.comment: This is cute, fast, portable, and novel. Of all the ones on this list, it may fade, since I don't have as many people who I play with, especially 2 player for whom this is likely a frequent opportunity, but it's fast and portable, so maybe it will. Nice chaotic feeling balance.

item.name: Minigolf Designer
item.comment:
If you like Kingdomino drafting but wish you were building something cooler than a generic kingdom, like perhaps a mini golf course, this may be for you. Lots of satisfying puzzle-y constraints to meet (par, layout, connections, guests, etc).

We almost forgot the passing rule, which makes the endgame work but makes it a bit more boring as many players pass until the right tiles come up.

Fun and good adaptation of the Kingdomino draft.

item.name: Mississippi
item.comment: See <a href=http://server.boardgamestuff.com:8000/gray/blog/Games/Reviews/Mississippi.html>my blog comments</a>

item.name: Mississippi Queen
item.comment: A solid core euro racing game.  Nothing amazing, but really solid and fun.

item.name: Mole Hill
item.comment: A great asymmetric game. It's got an entertaining learning curve, because of some non-obvious farmer strategies.

item.name: Monkey Madness
item.comment: Outstanding game 2- and 3-year-olds that, while lacking choices, is entertaining for even older kids.

item.name: Monsterjagd
item.comment: Cute twitch game.  Silly, light, quick.

item.name: Montanara
item.comment: Not much game here and not that interesting.

item.name: Monza
item.comment: Cute/fun kids' game I can play with my almost-3-year-old.  Rating is for that audience.  With adults, it's still probably a 5 or 6.

item.name: Mr. President
item.conditiontext:
Originally from Sid Sackson's personal collection
offervalue:30

item.name: Mü & More
item.comment: I actually really really like this game at some level, but I find myself uninterested in "making the commitment" of playing enough to learn it well to really get the most out of it.  When it comes down to it, if I'm going to play a trick taking game, there's any number of others I'll go to first (Schnaeppchen Jagd, Foppen, notably).

item.name: Muse
item.comment: Simplified approach to the Mysterium or Dixit kind of cluing. Especially nice art.

item.name: My City
item.comment: Fun parallel polyomino game with progressive variation over the course of a legacy game. Polyomino games aren't really my thing, but this is fast, interesting, and captures both the efficiency goal that's hard to avoid in polyomino games and interesting variations.

item.name: My First Carcassonne
item.comment: Minimal choices, but fun & quick kids game with some choices and a good dynamic.

item.name: Mystery Garden
item.comment: One of my 4-year-old's favorites.  Essentially a formalized version of 20 questions, but with only 15 questions.

item.name: Mystic Paths
item.comment: Fun cluing game in the spirit of Codenames or Decrypto with a fun novel mechanic around the paths.

item.name: Near and Far
item.comment: Very nice adventure game.

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment: Interesting, but not deeply compelling and the nature and magnitude of some of the point swings in the end game seem to make this less interesting.  I'll try it again, but don't need to buy it.

item.name: Nekojima
item.wishlistcomment: Felix put it on his watchlist, sounds interesting

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! 3.0
item.comment: Simple, fun war-gamish game.  It's got lots of little rules, but the interactions of them is the whole point of the game.  We started out playing slowly, and it was ok.  We were running out of time so had to play very fast, and it's much better that way.

item.name: The Newlywed Game
item.comment: Fun under the right circumstances.

item.name: Next Station: London
item.comment:
I only played it once and would be willing to play a second or more time, but it mostly feels like an above average roll&write.  

But as a genre, r&w's cap out well below "great" for me.  For someone who somehow loves r&w, I can see this being among the best, maybe?

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: Quick, entertaining, and fun family game that's got more to it than many seem to give it credit.

item.name: The Ninth World: A Skillbuilding Game for Numenera
Notre Dame
item.comment: Clever, fun with a reasonable variety of strategies to explore.

item.name: Oathsworn: Into the Deepwood
item.comment:
Only played once, to see what all the hype/buzz was.  I was totally prepared for it to be good but underwhelming, after all, all the love is probably about the giant miniatures and the "story", right?  Well, those are cool, but also a great game. I bought it.

I've only played twice yet, but very excited to play more. Replaying the same scenario (with different Oathsworn) was quite good too.

item.name: Oh, Pharaoh!
item.comment: A bit bland, and too much "take that" for my taste.  A little long for what it is.

item.name: Old Town
item.comment: Clever pseudo-deduction.  I'm not sure how much real control there is, but it's neat.

item.name: On Tour
item.comment: A good roll-and-write, not my favorite genre, but a good one in that genre.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
One Deck Dungeon
item.comment: Too hard, and too much of the difficulty driven by luck to be fun.  Rules are also a bit disappointing.  It's a shame because there's so much else about this that I really want to like more.

item.name: 単語探知機タンタンゴ (Word Detector Tantango)
item.comment:
2-dimensional "Wavelength" would be an apt description.

Played from a translation and used "Taboo" cards for words instead of translating the Japanese, but worked well enough.  At least with 5 players, it felt like the number of available "dimensions" that could be chosen for cluing was too much and it might have been more entertaining if there were fewer of those, which would be an easy enough adaptation.

That said, it's not always easy, and was definitely fun.

item.name: Oriente
item.comment: Badly written rules didn't help here.

item.name: Orléans
item.comment: Clever bag building, I wish it were faster and preserved much of what makes it great.

item.name: Pack & Stack
item.comment: Fun, light geometry game.  We played with a variant for 5: Winner of the previous round flips two trucks.  Also, none of this random draw for the last player.

item.name: Paint the Roses
item.comment: Fun, if overproduced, coop deduction game.  I like the idea and should play more with the challenges, but somehow it isn't something I've pulled back  to the table.

item.name: The Palace of Mad King Ludwig
Paperback Adventures
item.comment:
Solo games aren't really my thing but we had a pandemic so...

This is very much Slay the Spire made into a word-making solo card game; lots of monsters, items, upgrades and characters.

An extremely cool concept, but mega fiddly. Choices and strategies are novel and compelling, but messy gameplay. But, really engaging new constraints on an anagramming game.

I'm conflicted. Maybe not for me or maybe less fiddly on replay, or maybe cool enough to offset the complexity? Rating might go up, but we'll see.

item.name: Pastiche: The Birth of a Masterpiece
item.comment: A really clever twist on a rummy game, and it really feels like you learn some interesting things about the strategy and the endgame in your first several plays.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
Pax Renaissance
item.comment: Too many rules, and not enough in a good way.  To many surprises in the too many rules, and too area-influency to top it all off.   An unpleasant experience.

item.name: Pelican Cove
item.wishlistcomment: aka Uluru

item.name: Pente
item.comment:
Also known as Ninuki (or Ninuki-Renju) this is an extremely satisfying and quick
                                                   two player abstract.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: I really want to like this, but I find it far to mechanical without feeling like the choices are compelling and interesting rather than annoying.

item.name: Pico 2
item.comment: One of the deepest games you can player in under 5 minutes.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
Planet Unknown
item.comment:
A good polyomino game and I like it but I'm a little surprised by the magnitude of hype around it.

Only 2 plays so far, will play more.

item.name: Pocket Battles: Elves vs. Orcs
item.comment: Seems like a decent minis combat game.  Not really my thing.

item.name: Pocket Paragons
item.comment: A cute relatively pure simultaneous action selection game, which I tend to like. The characters seem to have some interesting variety, but given how quick it is, it's really hard to evaluate after only 6 plays.

item.name: Poison
item.comment: This was good. Not amazing, not revolutionary, but quick, a nice refinement of the Too Many Cooks mechanic and fun. It's a shame it's so overproduced. If Amigo (or someone else) comes out with a version in the small "standard" card box size, I'll definitely pick it up. Otherwise, I'll hold on to that shelf space and play someone else's copy.
item.wishlistcomment: Only want the Amigo or other small edition, if it exists.

item.name: Poisson d'Avril
item.comment: Gets pulled out once a year and generally isn't as entertaining as most people seem to think.  Actually, sort of annoying.

item.name: Pompeji
item.comment: A good little filler "tile laying" game.  The card art leaves something to be desired, but not bad.

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment: At least it's fast.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: For a game that _sounds_ really mundane and mechanical from reading the rules, it's really far from mundane, and the mechanics are just the right amount of different things to have to keep track of to keep this as an all-time classic.

item.name: Power Grid: The New Power Plants – Set 1
Der Prestel Kunstmarkt
item.comment: Fun little requirements-matching game.  The pieces are pretty, but sacrifice convenience of play for that beauty.  The rating would be higher, but I feel like it is likely to lose somewhat on repeat play.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: One of the all time classics.  When it comes down to it, the constraints of this game (you win 7 auctions and take 14 actions.  Period.) make it remarkably analyzable, without usually falling to bad analysis-paralysis, largely because there remain multiple effective paths to winning.

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: There is something very appealing about this, and it's a well constructed set of rules, etc. etc, but it just ends up feeling to dry/mechanical to excel.

item.name: Il Principe
item.comment: Not for me, but I can see others enjoying it.  The way the mechanics combine feels "clunky" somehow.

item.name: Printing Press
item.wishlistcomment: This seems very interesting and in that short-game sweet spot.

item.name: Professor Evil and The Citadel of Time
Puerto Rico
item.comment: Surprisingly reasonable to teach to newcomers and it deserves all the praise it gets.

item.name: Puerto Rico: Expansion I – New Buildings
item.comment: Fun variation on the usual buildings.

item.name: Quadtria
item.comment: A sort of unremarkable abstract.

item.name: Queendomino
item.comment: A demonstration of the corollary to the less-is-more principal.  Kingdomino is less (rulesy) and is far better and usually I like "rulesy".

item.name: Quietville
item.comment: Standard Schacht.  Good, interesting mechanisms, somewhat interesting play, no "spark".

item.name: Quirky Circuits
item.comment:
A great coop programming game.  Requires embracing the chaos, but the variety of robots and spectrum of difficulty of the games/puzzles here is great.

With less experienced and/or non-engineer players, it can feel like a wrench is being thrown in the works, but often that's a part of the fun.

Don't play with someone who will be annoyed by the lack of control or the errors of other players.

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: Fun, and easily handicapped (different number of fences) with kids.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: Very Ingenious-like, but different and clever enough to be fun on its own.

item.name: R.U.M.B.L.
item.comment: This sounds right up my alley, and I like much of Greg's other stuff, but this just was too far over the line of chaotic without control. That said, the mechanics are clever and interesting, and the score is likely to go up if I ever play again, but not sure by how much.

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
This may be my favorite auction game. Rather different from a traditional auction
                                                   game, it borrows aspects from several other games as well as a few novel bits of its
                                                   own. The discrete nature of the bidding tiles, the wide range of scoring options, the
                                                   simple but important strategic decision of when to call an auction and the reasonably
                                                   playing time combine to make this an outstanding game.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
I've been "seriously" gaming for 10+ years, played nearly 1000 different titles and for the first time, without equivocation, I can answer the "What's your favorite game?" question.   An [b]outstanding[/b] game in the style of San Juan (actually it's the other way around).  The art is exceptional.  The game is fast, but full of compelling tactical options, interesting combinations, engaging thematic elements and numerous strategies to pursue.  In the less than a year since it's been out, it's become my 3rd most played game ever and I have no doubt it will be the most played before long. 

EDIT/UPDATE: >5 years after I wrote this comment and all of the above remains true, and it's become my most played game.  I mostly only play with the first two expansions, without takeover rules, but enjoy all of the expansions.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Alien Artifacts
Race for the Galaxy: Rebel vs Imperium
Race for the Galaxy: The Brink of War
Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
Race! Formula 90
item.comment:
I guess too simulation-y for a theme I'm not excited about simulating?
Overall too dry and too slow without the decisions feeling important enough.  On repeated play, I'm guessing the decisions would become more meaningful, but it's not fun enough for me to want to play repeatedly.

item.name: Race! Formula 90: 2nd Edition
item.comment:
This is fine, but it lacks any special feeling for me.  The card mechanism is clever, but in the end it doesn't feel like I want a race game to feel.  The passing is often too restricted in terms of options, which I hear may be "realistic" but didn't feel "fun".  Also, fairly long for how good it is.

It's fine, and for someone really fond of racing games or the racing theme, I can see it being better.

item.name: Radlands
item.comment:
Only 3 plays so far, and there's some boost here for my enthusiasm for the potential this seems to have.

Our games have ended very quickly and felt rather luck driven, which is a mixed bag.

Rating could go up or down.

item.name: Ready Set Bet
item.comment: Not my favorite kind of chaos. In the right circumstances, fun, but I find the non-realtime similar games like Royal Turf to be more what I want in a being game.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: Failed to grab me.  I don't feel like the mechanics hang well together, it has just a bit too much take-that-ism and is prone to slow play.  Oh, and I find it annoying for reasons I can't quite put my finger on.

item.name: Return to Dark Tower
item.comment: I never owned the original, but had a friend that did, and I had a lot of positive nostalgia for the original. The remake is very very different, but is a really interesting coop resource management game. The app-supported aspect isn't my favorite, but the strategy seems compelling and the vibe of the game is perfect.

item.name: Ricochet Robot
item.comment:
Some people really like this sort of puzzle solving game, and others don&#039;t. I tend to
                                                   enjoy them. If you don&#039;t like puzzles, this may not be right for you, but if you do, it&#039;s a
                                                   great set up for a puzzle, and the simple

item.name: Risk: The Lord of the Rings Trilogy Edition
Robin Hood
item.comment: Clever little physical/memory mechanism that drives movement.  Very much a kids game.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment:
A much better experience the second time around.  The rules have no excuse for being this bad.  Thank goodness for the Quickstart guide in the files section here on BGG.

Still ended up getting one rule wrong that made it a bit too easy, but reasonably fun survival game.

This is very much a "random event cards produce a story" kind of games, and if dealing with planning/survival through those is appealing this is nicely done in that space.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment:
RoboRally, despite being an American game, was the game that really turned me on to
                                                   Designer/German games. Despite being a long, and to many people, complicated
                                                   game, I played a lot of this, and was fortunate enough to get all the expansions before
                                                   they, and the main game, went out of print in the US. I highly recommend this game,
                                                   especially to those with a technical bent. I haven't played it much recently (4 times in
                                                   the past 2 years), but I expect to occasionally play it for many years to come.
item.conditiontext:
Want new Avalon Hill edition
wantvalue:25

item.name: Robot Quest Arena
item.comment:
Only two plays, rating might go up.

I had high hopes for this and it fell a bit short of that.  So, this is pretty negative, but it's against a background of high expectations: It felt rather chaotic and not as much of a "fun mess" way as other games. The deck building feels good but a little slower than is interesting.  More deck thinning availability might make it more interesting.  There were lots of opportunities to one-shot or two-shot an opponent and at the end game the constant re-spawn felt less fun than I'd hoped.

On a second play, my feeling didn't go down, but maybe up a bit, but I worry there's not any real depth.  But, it's fun enough and I'm going to play more.

The cards are interesting and diverse, and the robots are adorable.

item.name: Robot Turtles
item.comment: Not appealing, even as a kids game.  I don't expect kids games to be deep, but I expect them to "feel" more like a game, and this doesn't have interesting choices, even for children, or feel like a game in the ways I want.

item.name: Rogue Angels: Legacy of the Burning Suns
Roll Camera!: The Filmmaking Board Game
Roll Player
item.comment: Too long but surprisingly thematically evocative dice drafting and manipulation game.  If it were shorter and captured most of the same crunch, it could be really great.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: A very good execution of a dice-civ game.  Exactly what it sounds like.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: Interesting, and I haven't had the chanc e to explore all the interactions.  Don't get to play it enough.

item.name: Root
item.comment:
The game isn't a bad game, and in many ways it's a clever design, but I hated the experience of playing this.  Part of it was that the different roles sort of lock you into a play style and I did not enjoy the play style of my role (the cats).  I suppose this could/would apply for many wargames, but this somehow was distinctively unpleasant to play.  I can imagine others enjoying it, and the strategic choices were "interesting" but not enjoyable to make.  Tense games can be good, but this was all unpleasant tension for me.  Oh well.  It's adorable.

In contrast, I enjoyed Vast, so maybe it was just the feel of it?

item.name: Rotundo
item.comment: Odd Adlung game about collecing spherical objects. Not awful, but nothing too inspired and definitely an odd theme. I bet if you translated it to English and named it "Balls!", you'd get sales on the name alone. Gameplay has an interesting bit or two but ends up feeling mundane.

item.name: Rum & Pirates
item.comment: We didn't even play all the rounds.  It could be worse, but I doubt I will be convinced to try it again.

item.name: Rumis
item.comment:
Pueblo-like game of building using 3 dimensional blocks. It scores differently, in fact nearly opposite and the gameplay is somewhat different (your pieces must touch your other pieces). Overall, its good, perhaps has good or better then Pueblo. Plus, it comes with a nice "Lazy Susan" style board which Pueblo would benefit from.

Plays very well with younger kids (mine are 6&4).

item.name: Rutschpartie mit Winnie the Pooh
item.comment: Rating as a kids game.

item.name: Sag's mit Symbolen
item.comment: We played this, thinking it would be a nice light not-quite-party-game. Oops. It's an odd little pseudo-deduction/clue-giving game. It's actually got some rather interesting and difficult decisions. It'd be nice to have it in English, but using a translation sheet wasn't bad.

item.name: Sakkara
item.comment: Not bad, but didn't impress or disappoint.

item.name: San Francisco
item.comment:
A very cool variant of the Coloretto mechanic for drafting, with a neat twist where taking more sets than your opponents limits your options. The city building is good typical Euro fare. Plus, 3d skyscrapers and streetcars.

I probably won't pick it up, but if I didn't already have a jillion middle weight Euros or had a stronger affinity for SF, I might.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: Outstanding game that's fun to try out the many different strategies and rewards rapid adaption (to both card draw and other players' behavior).  Scales well from 2 to 4 players.  Lowered rating to a 9 just because Race so completely trumps it.

item.name: Schwarzarbeit
item.comment: Unusually clever deduction game which isn't just a straight note-taking logic-puzzle endeavor.  I like a deduction game that rewards informed guessing.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: I get it's an all-time classic but while the anagramming/crosswording aspect is good, in the end, the geometry for casual players is not interesting enough.

item.name: Sentinel Tactics: The Flame of Freedom
Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment:
Amazing, fiddly, beautiful implicit superhero narrative.  The combos are great, the gameplay memorable (if you have the patience for the fiddliness), and the variety amazing.

One of the best games of all time in my book.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Infernal Relics
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Shattered Timelines
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Villains of the Multiverse
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Wrath of the Cosmos
Sequence
item.comment: Perfectly decent "N-in-a-row" game.  The obfuscation of the grid by using cards feels weird.  It clearly makes the game feel familiar and less intimidating for some, and makes it more likely to "miss"  that a play is possible, which seems like a downside.  It's fine.

item.name: SET
item.comment:
This is a very clever little filler game, which my wife is upsettingly good at. It can be a
                                                   bit of a brain burner, but it&#039;s engaging and quick. It is one of the few

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: Gorgeous and fun but the gameplay itself is pretty dull and abstract.  I substantially prefer the LOTR cooperative game (with or without Sauron).

item.name: Shadows: Amsterdam
item.comment: Enjoyable realtime variation of the Mysterium core mechanic.  Fun, light and novel transformation of the Mysterium and Codenames mechanics into a race game.

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment: The Aardman-esque sheep are really cute, but when it comes down to it, it's an abstract puzzle game and really not that interesting of one. Plus, it seems to have some kingmaker issues which is even more annoying in a puzzle game.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment: A fine lying game.  With the right group dynamic, fun enough. Not interesting enough to be something I'd seek out.

item.name: The Shipwreck Arcana
item.comment: Fun, light, fast coop deduction and delivers on all those attributes.  Some of the deductions are easy, but many nicely give that feeling of being clever (even if it may be a bit of an illusion).  Very well done.

item.name: The Siege of Runedar
item.comment: I like coops, it's been a while since Knizia did a big coop, and I was happy with this one as a novel kind of coop deck builder. I think, even on the easy setting, it's a little too hard, which is a shame, but it's still a really enjoyable experience.

item.name: Singapore
item.comment: I found this amusingly frustrating. I play a lot of crowed-funded games and like a lot of them. One of the common critiques of them is that they lead to "underdeveloped" games. Singapore feels like an old-school-Euro-style game (though still conspicuously post-Caylus) that is just underdeveloped. We even played with a variant because Felix felt like it was a necessary fix, and from only having it played it this way, I suspect he's right. But, it really felt like it was still missing several development opportunities. I think Felix has another variant rule to try next time, it just probably won't be with me.

item.name: Sixto
item.comment:
The rules describe it as a "typical roll and write" and that's a pretty perfect summary.

R&W is not my favorite genre, and this does nothing special, interesting, or clever.  It's fine, but super-generic.  If you love R&Ws, this is indeed yet another roll & write.

I don't need to play it again, but it's quick.

item.name: Sky Team
item.comment:
(only one play)

The intro scenario is very easy but the core coop dice-placement mechanic works well and the whole set of modules is very appealing.  Even easy it feels like an interesting cooperative exercise.

I don't usually like "worker placement" games, but the solo games I enjoy the most are dice worker placement, so at some level it shouldn't be surprising that I enjoy that in a coop too.

Eagerly looking forward to more play when I can get a copy.

item.name: Sluff Off!
item.comment: I think I'd mostly rather play Spades, but it's somewhat novel.

item.name: Sneaks & Snitches
item.comment: I don't think I'd ever play this over Hick Hack in Gacklewack.

item.name: So Clover!
item.comment: I have enjoyed the cooperative party game surge that's been going on lately with games like Just One and Master Word, but this is a stand out, up there with Just One. It's funny, it's an interesting deduction and cluing problem, and it's satisfying when you win. It's nice to see a novel and clever twist on the whole "juxtaposing words is often funny" mechanic that sort of got overdone for a while. Approachable, and gets brought out a lot. Highly recommended.

item.name: SolForge Fusion
item.comment:
Only played once, but this does a number of clever/novel things in this kind of dueling psuedo-CCG space that I really like, and those are independent of the core conceit as a random/algorithmically generated set of decks.

I didn't back it on KS, and I don't exactly regret not backing it, but I wouldn't have been disappointed at all if I did.  This is fun, interesting, and different.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Wow.  Absolutely amazing combination of 3 things I like a lot (cooperative, programmed movement, rich sci-fi theme) and one thing I like fine (realtime) makes for an exceptional and novel game.  I can't get it out of my head.

item.name: Space Beans
item.comment: Best if played _fast_.  Slow play breaks this game down a lot, since it becomes too easy to memorize everything that's going on.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment: Very entertaining and engaging.  "Balancing" the timer split among players is important though.

item.name: Space Station Assault
item.comment: New in shrink.

item.name: Speed
item.comment:
I&#039;d picked this up at Essen in 2000, and hadn&#039;t played it much. Then, for some reason,
                                                   I picked it up again in summer of 2001, and haven&#039;t stopped playing it. For a game that
                                                   plays in under 60 seconds, it is surprisingly satisfying, and lends itself well to the

item.name: SpellBook
item.comment:
(one play)
Appealing "engine builder" of a sort that plays quickly.  It seems like the actions are often both fairly obvious and subject to fairly swingy luck.  Many of the control actions just net too few resources to be worth the trade-off of the amount of control they give you in terms of what you get.  Over the course of several actions, drawing 2 per action is just better than swapping or choosing from a very limited pool 1 per action.

In the end, not bad, but a little disappointing.

item.name: Spinball
item.comment: One of the top few dexterity games ever.

item.name: Spirit Island
item.comment:
One of the best, if not *the* best complex coop games.  It's not *too* hard by default with good options for increased difficulty and such.  The card and Spirit variety are great and the triple advancement of the spirit power, settlers, and fear works really well.

It's only real weakness is that it is fairly analysis paralysis prone and not short.  With 2 players, that's somewhat mitigated.

item.name: Spot it!
item.comment: Any game where deconstructing the design leads to an understanding of combinatoral block design is a good first step.  But, not required to play, and it's fun.

item.name: Spots
item.comment:
Adorable little push-your-luck game with a bit of randomness in both the cards and the dice, but seems to have reasonable mitigation mechanics.

Only one play, but not bad.

item.name: Star Quest
item.comment: New in shrink.

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: The best 2-player hit-each-other deck builder IMO.

item.name: Star Scrappers: Orbital
item.comment: I don't love worker placement, I dislike area influence, and I really dislike "take that", but despite having all three of these this is better than most games with those attributes, but still not for me.

item.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Next Generation – Next Phase
item.comment:
I really want to like this game more.  It has so many things I like:
 - Deck builder!
 - Star Trek theme!
 - Coop mode!
 - Interesting thematic connection to mechanics!

Unfortunately, it's... not great.  It's too long.  It often feels like you don't have any good choices or options.  It's very subject to the randomness of the space deck.

I so want this to be better than it is.

item.name: Star Trek: Missions
item.comment: I would love for this to be better than Fantasy Realms and/or Marvel Remix because it's an even more appealing theme, but it feels too much more constrained and falls short. But, it does the core of these games reasonably well, and FR or MR being too "wide open" is a downside, maybe this is for you?

item.name: Star Wars: Destiny
item.comment: Nice custom-dice dueling game with quick turns and interesting tempo decisions.  Plays pretty quick and has some satisfying moments.  It's different enough in the way it works from other similar games to be appealing.

item.name: Star Wars: Episode 1 – Clash of the Lightsabers
Star Wars: Episode 1 – Clash of the Lightsabers
Star Wars: Jabba's Palace – A Love Letter Game
item.comment:
Fun love letter variant.  No better than the base, but different and similarly good. The additional victory goals are a nice addition.

1 play.

item.name: Star Wars: The Deckbuilding Game
item.comment:
This is delightfully good, and not just a pure rehash of Star Realms, though it's similarity is clear.  Several interesting mechanical twists relative to Star Realms and some nice integration of the theme.

Our game went weirdly long and I wonder if we spent too much time buying cards and capital ships that caused the game to drag a bit.  Our game was probably over 90 minutes, and we only played to defeat 3 bases.  At the advertised 30 minutes, this might be really great.

item.name: Stars of Akarios
item.comment: A Kickstarter I skipped, but I don't know what I was thinking, so I paid full retail, substantially more than the KS price, and I am extremely happy with it. As a cooperative campaign/legacy tactical adventure game, this has been described as "Gloomhaven in Space" and clearly it is heavily inspired by Gloomhaven, but it has a lot of good divergences as well as borrowing a lot of goodness. First, it's in space. That makes any game better. Second, a large chunk of the game is interesting dice allocation and persistent limited uses powers. The narrative is cheesy but 10 scenarios in, I'm eager for more. The character/ship development is interesting, the space battles are stellar, and the planet exploration is good and feels consequential. I love it.

item.name: Starship Captains
item.comment: Good worker placement.  Very acceptable, but nothing amazing.  The theme is great.  The art is great.  The gameplay is fine.  If you like worker placement, you might really like this.

item.name: Starship Merchants
item.comment:
This is a really well crafted game, with an interesting theme, witha core set of mechanics that I just don't like that much.

It's a pick-up-and-deliver game with spaceship purchasing, obsolescence  technologies, pilots, mining claims, etc, but at it's core it's an economic pick-up-and-deliver game like some railroad games, and even though I like the idea of that kind of game, I don't find myself that fond of them in actual play.

There do seem to be a variety of reasonable strategies and cool options, and interesting tempo aspects to the game.  The total scale of the end game compared to the cost of ships makes the game feel even more about precision timing, and less about the strategies chosen.  This is, again, a less favored style of game for me.

item.name: Strange Synergy
item.comment: It's random, chaotic, horribly unbalanced, often sort of tedious, and in some cases actually downright broken, but for some reason I like it a lot.

item.name: Streetcar
item.comment: A nice combination of route/connection mechanics with hidden goals.

item.name: Strozzi
item.comment: Rating may well go up.  Seems like a clever intersection of Medici and Ra.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: Nice mechanics that combine together to form a tedious mechanical wargamey experience.  Not my thing at all.

item.name: Subastral
item.comment: Beautiful game with interesting novel card drafting and novel set collection mechanics.  Clever.

item.name: Succession: Intrigue in the Royal Court
Sudoku Challenge
item.comment: Nothing amazing, but a decent conversion of Sudoku into a game that's better than parallel puzzle solving.

item.name: Sunrise Lane
item.wishlistcomment: Felix put it on his watchlist, sounds interesting

item.name: Sushi Express
item.comment: Super random, super light, quite fast, not bad.

item.name: Tabula Rasa
item.comment: A solid flag-influence game, fun and quick.

item.name: Take it Easy!
item.comment:
Supports from 2-10 players, plays quick, and involves psychedelic colors. This is a
                                                   multiplayer solitaire game that&#039;s a lot of fun, though there are variants that add a
                                                   small amount of player interaction that are fun as well. It ends up feeling like

item.name: Techno Witches
item.comment: Surprisingly engaging pre-programmed measured movement race game. The components are nice and the mechanics are clever. My only wish is they had components for more than 4 players. It cries out for a Harry Potter brand licensing.

item.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shadows of the Past
Terra Prime
item.comment: A bit harsh and not that fun.  And the production values are a little embarassing.

item.name: Terraforming Mars: Ares Expedition – Discovery · Foundations · Crisis
Terraforming Mars: The Dice Game
item.comment:
(3 plays so far, one solo)
More different from base TM than AE, but still faithful, and at least somewhat shorter, but not a lot.  I wish it was even shorter, but it feels like it might have potential on repeat play to go faster, but maybe not.

I like the production/action turn dichotomy a lot and the resource management feels compellingly different than many games, and the core TM card/engine building works well.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: Mechanically captures the feel of research/execution, making the theme work very well.  It's only weakness is the tile draw is a bit too random, but it's very close to being "just right".

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
Through the Desert
item.comment: Excellent and approachable.  Multiple paths to victory though "longest camel chain" seems often underestimated.

item.name: Thunder Road: Vendetta
item.comment:
Very well done adaptation of the original. Utter chaos.

The best beer and pretzels game in recent memory.

https://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/148320/thunder-road-vendetta-thoughts

item.name: Thurn und Taxis: Der Kurier der Fürstin
Tichu
item.comment: Blah.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Quite good, but I don't find it as revolutionary as many.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: I like it a bit better than the "US" version.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: A good tight 2/3 player map, but the rules tweaks seem just distracting/confusing compared to the other versions.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
item.comment: This is a really nice variant route set.

item.name: Tiger & Dragon
item.comment:
Cute, beautiful components little trick taking game of a sort.  Some of the gameplay seems straightforward, or maybe just a bit random (dependent on what other players have in hand without much signaling of what), but has some good exciting moments as you hope for a tile to go around.

There may be more depth there than it initially seems, and the decisions are fine, and I'd definitely give it another try at some point, but it didn't stand out.

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment:
Very light fun game of temporal trivia.  We've had especially good experiences with teenagers and the quality of learning something about history in the process is just the game, not some weird educational layer on top.

Very approachable with non-gamers.

item.name: Tiny Epic Dungeons
item.comment:
Very appealing, but very hard, coop dungeon crawl.

Detailed thoughts: https://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/128181/tiny-epic-dungeon-gives-me-descent-feeling

item.name: Tiny Epic Dungeons: Potions & Perils Mini Expansion
Titan: The Arena
item.comment:
Good bluffing/betting game.  In this vein I prefer the simpler/faster versions like Flinke Pinke, but the powers here are a nice twist and makes for some good variety.

Allegedly best with 3 and I think I agree, and my last play was with 3, but I've not played enough to say so with certainty. It definitely seems like more than 3 there's less control and it bogs down a bit.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: An outstanding dice game, better with fewer rather than more, since it plays more quickly.

item.name: Tongiaki: Journey into the Unknown
item.comment: It's chaotic and fun, and the right length (short) for that combination.  Plus, lots of opportunity for clever plays and amusing interactions.

item.name: Too Many Cinderellas
item.comment: Cute clever fast, shallow and falls short of some other 18-card games out there, but cute and not bad.

item.name: Toppo
item.comment: Fun speed pattern recognition in the mold of Set or Oraklos.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: I find it tedious, dry and mundane.

item.name: Tower of Babel
item.comment: I think I've enjoyed this more with fewer than with more, but I haven't played it enough to be sure.

item.name: Tranquility
item.comment:
1 play. Takes up a lot of table space for a small game.

Promising limited communication coop, but may have a limited shelf life.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: Despite many complaints that the strategic depth of this maxes out quickly, I find this has had a great deal of longevity and remains fun despite the relative ease with which many people seem to think they can find the optimal strategy.

item.name: Traumfabrik
item.comment:
This is an outstanding Knizia auction/set-collecting game, worthy of inclusion of the
                                                   oft-cited Knizia auction

item.name: Traveller Customizable Card Game: Two Player Starter Set
Tribond
item.comment:
Formerly owned by Sid Sackson! (with stamp, from his estate auction)
Slight shelf wear, quite good condition.

item.name: Triology
item.comment: Exceedingly brain burningly intense and not much fun for all that effort.  Drags awfully as a result.  Play Set instead.

item.name: Turbo
item.comment: Cute speed game.

item.name: Twilight Imperium: Third Edition
item.comment: Cool bits, fun concept, but for it's length, there's others I'll much more eagerly play.

item.name: Twilight of the Gods: Age of Revelation
Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
When I first saw and read about this, I immediately assumed I wouldn't like it.  It's a long, historical area influence game, all strikes against a game in my book.  So, I didn't play it.

Nearly a year later, everyone continues to rave about it, and it seems to have nearly universal appeal, so I decided to give it a try.  I read more about it and become more inclined to think I'd like it.  It's a card-driven system, similar to We The People which is a rare long, historical game I LIKE.  I was really looking forward to trying it.

Finally, I tried it.  It was interesting, and I didn't dislike the experience, but mostly all of my initial concerns turned out to be true.  It just doesn't do it for me.  Under the right circumstances I could be convinced to play it again, and I understand why some people like it, but I can't say I understand the overwhelming positivity toward this game.

item.name: Twister
item.conditiontext:
Formerly owned by Sid Sackson, still in shrink.
offervalue:15

item.name: Twixt
item.comment: One of the great connection games, and works with very young kids, at least mechanically.

item.name: Typo
item.comment:
See
<a href=http://server.boardgamestuff.com:8000/gray/blog/Games/Reviews/Typo.html>my blog comments</a>

item.name: Ubongo
item.comment: Cute speed puzzle solving, surprising it hasn't been done before.

item.name: ...und tschüss!
item.comment: Good game, but I'd rather play 6 nimmt!  I find this just too short and luck driven.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment: Never got much out of it.

item.name: Unlock!: Escape Adventures – The Island of Doctor Goorse
Unsettled
item.comment:
The game is beautiful, with great components, and an imperfect but still very good rulebook. It's definitely a little more narrative-y than I expected, but still strategic, engaging and fun.

 It is what it promises: Thematic sci-fi exploration with a puzzle-y action point mechanic. The tube is the writing and "puzzles" is great.  

From now on, I'm playing with "read ahead" of the missions, since some of them are a little bait and switch in terms of goals.

item.name: Urland
item.comment: Good game, but too long for what it is.  The turn timing is interesting.

item.name: Vabanque
item.comment: I really want to like this, and at some level I think I do, but every time I play it everyone else despises it so, I doubt I'll bring it out often because I don't want to inflict this on others.

item.name: Valdora
item.comment: A very good pick-up-and-deliver game, and those aren't usually my thing.

item.name: The Vale of Eternity
item.wishlistcomment: Felix put it on his watchlist, sounds interesting

item.name: Valor & Villainy: Lludwik's Labyrinth
item.comment: Nice coop dungeon crawl with a couple of clever bits and a weird, but charming narrative.  A bit rules fiddly, as these games are inevitably prone to, but both fun and interesting decisions, a little puzzly, a little bit of a romp, a little bit of a story, mostly a solid game.

item.name: Victory & Honor
item.comment: Very good trick taking game. In fact, one of the best new ones I've played in a while. The twist in this one is that you play three tricks ("left", "center" and "right") at a time. If you play a card to your "left" trick, your left hand opponent must play the next card. It's a little complicated to wrap a strategy around at first, but it's a lot of fun and very interesting. Clever.

item.name: Virus & Co
item.comment: Too much rules for too little game.

item.name: VisualEyes
item.comment: It's a cute mechanic that works surprisingly well.  There's enough combinations that it doesn't get stale quickly.

item.name: Viva Topo!
item.comment: Rated as a kids game.  An excellent little push-your-luck race game, where a variety of strategies are viable, depending how the dice fall.

item.name: Voidfall
item.wishlistcomment: Probably too long and not unique.

item.name: Walk the Dogs
item.comment: With kids, the rating would be much higher.

item.name: Wallenstein
item.comment: Not bad, but not that impressive.

item.name: We the People
item.wishlistcomment: oop

item.name: WFF 'N PROOF
item.comment: If you think doing formal logic proofs are fun, you'd probably have more fun sitting down and doing some proofs than playing this game.  If you don't think it sounds like fun, you certainly won't like it.

item.name: Whirling Witchcraft
item.comment: Fast, weird combo-building with a core mechanism that is somewhat random but fun and, again, novel. The entire core mechanic seems to confuse people in a delightful and engaging way.

item.name: Who Lives Where?
item.comment: Rated as a kids game.

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: Perhaps the best betting game out there.  Go Nougat!

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: Substantially better than average trivia game, with well structured questions, and it's fun.

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: Rummy games are not my thing, but other than Zirkus Flohcati, this is about as good as they get.

item.name: Wyrmspan
item.comment:
Not as good as Wingspan, IMO.  (I like dragons, but also like birds, and if you're super pro-dragon maybe this is as good?)

It's not a simple retheme of Wingspan, but it's also not *that* different (compared to, say, Earth which shares some aspects with Wingspan, but is quite a different game).

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
Yspahan
item.comment: It felt like it was too short to utilize a reasonable fraction of the game elements, but too long for the amount of luck and nature of the game

item.name: Zauberschwert & Drachenei
item.comment: Well designed, simple fantasy themed game, but not that engaging when it comes down to it.

item.name: Zicke Zacke Hühnerkacke
item.comment: One of the better straightforward memory games out there.

item.name: Zig-Zag
item.comment:
Cute little filler speed game.
With my 4-year-old we play a variant: Kids can keep going after an adult calls stop.  It works very well.

item.name: Zirkus Flohcati
item.comment:
I only recently discovered this game, and it is definitely in the filler category, but it's
                                                   really good filler. It's a good combination of jeapordy (flip one more card, or not?)
                                                   game and set collecting. The multiple paths to victory (despite claims I've read
                                                   elsewhere, the non-Gala players do win sometimes) makes it a quite filling little filler.

item.name: Zombie Kidz Evolution
item.comment: Rated As a kids game, played with children roughly age 6-10.
